questions.text: Which of the following statements is not included in the case definition of smallpox?

choices.text: Acute onset fever and malaise 2-4 days before onset of rash
Development of a maculopapular rash starting on the face and forearms
Evolution of the rash to umbilicated pustules within 48 hours
No alternative diagnosis explaining the illness

questions.solution:
The rash of smallpox evolves within 48 hours, to first form deep-seated, firm, and well-circumscribed vesicles, which later become umbilicated or confluent pustules.

Case definition for notification of smallpox:

  • An individual of any age with acute onset fever, malaise, severe prostration, headache, and backache 2-4 days before the onset of rash. 
  • Development of a maculopapular rash starting on the face and forearms and then spreading to the trunk and legs. Rash evolves within 48 hours to deep-seated, firm, and well-circumscribed vesicles, which later become umbilicated or confluent pustules.
  • Lesions that appear at the same stage of development (i.e. all are vesicles or all are pustules) on any given part of the body. 
  • No alternative diagnosis explaining the illness. 
  • Laboratory confirmation: Identification of variola (smallpox) DNA with PCR or isolation of the virus from a clinical specimen

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to you with complaints of fever and malaise. He also complains of an itchy rash which first appeared on the trunk as shown below. When is this disease the most contagious?

choices.text: After formation of scab
2 days before and 5 days after the onset of rash
7 days before to 7 days after the onset of rash
4 days before to 4 days after the onset of rash

questions.solution:
The rash (different stages at one time) in the image and the clinical history are suggestive of chickenpox. The period of communicability for chickenpox is 2 days before and 5 days after the onset of rash.

choices.text: Pleomorphic

questions.solution:
The rash of chickenpox is superficial and the rash of smallpox is deep-seated.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about chickenpox?
  1. It is caused by HHV 3
  2. The scab is infective
  3. A killed vaccine is used for prophylaxis
  4. The secondary attack rate is 85%
  5. The virus stays latent in the sensory ganglion
questions.solution:
Chickenpox is caused by the human herpes virus-3 (varicella-zoster virus). It remains latent in the sensory ganglion. Reactivation of the virus can cause shingles.

The secondary attack rate of chickenpox is very high, 85% (range 61%–100%).

The characteristic infective vesicle, surrounded by an erythematous halo, is described as a dewdrop on a rose petal. The scab of chickenpox is not infective.

The vaccine given for chickenpox prophylaxis is live attenuated vaccine.

questions.text: The varicella vaccine can be safely administered to which of the following individuals?

choices.text: A pregnant woman
A patient allergic to neomycin
A HIV infected patient with CD4+ T cell levels > 15%
A patient on long term corticosteroid therapy

questions.solution:
Varicella vaccine can be considered for clinically stable HIV infected children or adults with CD4+ T cell level ≥15%, including those receiving active antiretroviral therapy.

Varicella vaccine is contraindicated in:

  • Pregnant women
  • Immunocompromised patients
  • Patients allergic to neomycin

Following vaccination, salicylates should be avoided for 6 weeks to prevent Reye's syndrome.

questions.text: A child with a fever and rash was brought to your OPD. Oral findings as shown in the image were observed. During which period can this disease spread to others?

choices.text: 4 days before and 2 days after the appearance of rash
2 days before and 2 days after the appearance of rash
4 days before and 4 days after the appearance of rash
2 days before and 4 days after the appearance of rash

questions.solution:
The given image shows koplik spots, which are a pathognomonic sign of measles. The period of communicability for measles is 4 days before and 4 days after the appearance of rash. The patient is isolated for 7 days from the onset of rash.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about measles?

choices.text: Incubation period is 5 days
Otitis media is a common complication
It is caused by Orthomyxovirus
Large number of carriers are present

questions.solution:
The most common complication of measles is otitis media, occurring in about 10–15 % of patients.

Measles is caused by an RNA virus of the Paramyxovirus family. The incubation period of measles is 10 to 14 days. The only source of infection is a case of measles. Carriers are not known to occur. 

The complications of measles include:

  • Otitis media (most common)
  • Measles-associated diarrhea
  • Pneumonia
  • Conjunctivitis
  • Febrile seizures
  • Subacute sclerosing pan encephalitis (rare but is fatal) - occurs several years after primary infection

questions.text: During a measles epidemic in the community, an eight-and-a-half-month-old child was vaccinated for measles. What is the correct immunisation schedule to be followed for her, regarding measles?

choices.text: The child should be given a second dose after 4 weeks.
The child should be given a second dose as soon as she reaches 9 months of age.
The child should directly be given the second dose of measles at 16 months.
The child should be given the second dose of measles at 12 months of age.

questions.solution:
In this child, the next dose of measles vaccine should be given after 4 weeks.

While the scheduled age of receiving a measles vaccine is 9 months, it can be lowered up to 6 months during a measles epidemic in the community. 

For infants immunized between 6 to 9 months of age, a second dose should be administered as soon as the child reaches the age of 9 months. It is to ensure adequate immunity has developed, provided that 4 weeks have elapsed since the last dose. 

In this child, the first dose was given at the age of 8 and a half months, and there must be a gap of 4 weeks between the two doses. If the child were to be vaccinated as soon as she turns 9 months old, only two weeks would have been elapsed.

Measles Immunization Day is celebrated on the 16th of March every year to create awareness about this deadly disease. There is no specific treatment for measles but there is a vaccine to protect from the disease, which is both safe & cost-effective.

questions.text: A child was brought to you with complaints of fever, malaise and a rash. You diagnose the child with measles. What is the recommended period of isolation for this disease?

choices.text: From onset of rash to 3 days after rash
2 weeks before rash to 1 week after rash
From onset of rash to 5 days after rash
From catarrhal stage to 5 days after rash

questions.solution:
The isolation period for measles is from the catarrhal (prodromal) stage to 5 days after the onset of the rash. 

The period of communicability is approximately 4 days before and 5 days after the appearance of the rash. Isolation of the patient for a week from the onset of rash adequately covers the period of communicability.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the criteria for elimination of measles?

choices.text: There should be an absence of transmission of epidemic measles
The duration of absence of transmission should be  ≥ 6 months
A  well-performing surveillance system should be present
Absence of transmission should be seen in multiple geographical areas

questions.solution: Measles elimination is operationally defined as the absence of endemic measles transmission in a defined geographical area (region or country) for ≥12 months in the presence of a well-performing surveillance system.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the Measles-Rubella campaign?

choices.text: It is a mass vaccination campaign organised to introduce MR vaccine
Follow-up campaign is organised every 3-5 years
It covers children from 9 months to 15 years of age
Mop-up strategy is a part of the campaign

questions.solution:
Mop-up strategy is not a part of the Measles-Rubella campaign. 

Measles-Rubella vaccine introduction campaign:

  • A mass vaccination campaign to introduce an MR vaccine
  • Targets a wide age group of children: 9 months to < 15 years
  • All children in the target age group receive an additional dose of the vaccine
  • Regardless of previous vaccination status or history of illness. 

Measles-Rubella follow-up campaign:

  • A mass vaccination campaign as a periodic event every 3–5 years guided by country-specific surveillance data
  • Target age group for immunization: all children aged > 9 months, who were born after the previous MR vaccination campaign

questions.text: According to the WHO, what percentage of immunization coverage is needed for eradication of measles?
questions.solution: According to the WHO, eradication of measles requires achieving an immunization coverage of at least 96% of children under 1 year of age.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Rubella infection?

choices.text: It is a type of droplet infection
Vertical transmission is possible
Infection in early pregnancy causes a milder form of disease in the fetus
Fetus affected in late pregnancy may have only deafness

questions.solution:
Earlier the rubella infection occurs in pregnancy, greater is the damage to the foetus.

The major determinant of the extent of fetal infection in congenital rubella syndrome is the gestational age at which fetal transmission occurs.

Rubella infection in 1st trimester can cause:

  • Abortions
  • Still birth
  • Skin lesions - blueberry muffin rash
  • Congenital rubella syndrome

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: According to the WHO, which of the following tests cannot be used to confirm a case of swine flu?

choices.text: Real-time PCR
Viral culture
4-fold rise in virus specific neutralizing antibodies
ELISA

questions.solution:
ELISA is not included in the criteria for confirming a case of H1N1. 

The ELISA is an easy to perform, highly specific, and fairly sensitive diagnostic tool for the 2009 pandemic influenza A (H1N1) virus infections. However, it is not included in the WHO 's list of confirmation tests.

According to WHO, 2009 pandemic (H1N1) virus infection is confirmed by one or more of the following tests:

  • Polymerase chain reaction (PCR)
  • Viral culture
  • 4‐fold rise in H1N1 virus‐specific neutralizing antibodies

questions.text: What is the route of administration of avian influenza vaccine?

choices.text: Intranasal
Intramuscular
Subcutaneous
Intradermal

questions.solution:
The avian influenza H5N1 vaccine is administered intramuscularly.

H5N1 avian influenza vaccine was approved in 2017 for the age group of 18 to 64 years of age who are at increased risk of exposure to the H5N1 influenza virus subtype contained in the vaccine. 

It is administered intramuscularly in the upper arm and given in 2 doses, 28 days apart.

Note: The live attenuated H1N1 influenza vaccine is given intranasally.

questions.text: Vaccine that requires strain change due to evolving organism is?

choices.text: Influenza
Diphtheria
Polio
Typhoid

questions.solution:
Influenza vaccine requires periodic strain change due to antigenic change in the surface glycoprotein of the virus.

The change may be gradual (antigenic drift) or drastic (antigenic shift).

questions.text: Pandemic that occurred in 2009 was due to which influenza virus?

choices.text: H1N1
H5N1
H5N7
H3N2

questions.solution:
Recent influenza pandemic occurred in 2009 due to the emergence of a novel H1N1 influenza A virus.

Past influenza pandemics:

  • 1968 pandemic due to H3N2 virus
  • 1957-58 pandemic due to H2N2 virus
  • 1918 pandemic due to H1N1 virus
